headline: Ronna McDaniel on healthcare fix, tax cuts, Sessions attacks
subHeadline: RNC chairwoman speaks out on 'Your World'

utterances.speaker: NEIL CAVUTO, HOST
utterances.sentences: All right, reaction all of this. Ronna McDaniel joins us, the chairwoman of the Republican National Committee.  Very good to see you again. How you doing?

utterances.speaker: RONNA ROMNEY MCDANIEL, CHAIR, REPUBLICAN NATIONAL COMMITTEE
utterances.sentences: Oh, great. Great to be here. Thanks for having me, Neil.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: All right, I do want to talk about little bit about, well, everything here, the health care thing. The president is no doubt watching that closely. You are watching this closely. We're told, on the health care fight here, that it might all come down to a skinny repeal, sort of something that can be mutually agreed on by everybody, but that barely changes the needle.  What do you think?

utterances.speaker: ROMNEY MCDANIEL
utterances.sentences: Well, I think we have to get it to conference. And I think that's the goal.  Getting it to the floor was critical yesterday, that vote. And, of course, Senator McCain being the final vote and Mike Pence being the tiebreaker was critical.   Now we can have the discussion. We're going to have debate for the next day or so, and then they will add the amendments Thursday, and then the hope is to get it to conference, so that the House and the Senate can work together to find a bill that everyone can agree on, and we can finally repeal and replace ObamaCare and help the American people.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: All right, now, the repeal measure itself that Senator Rand Paul wanted was shot down, seven Republicans among those rejecting it, including John McCain. What did you make of it?

utterances.speaker: ROMNEY MCDANIEL
utterances.sentences: I don't think it was unexpected. The senators had come out last week and said that they wouldn't support the straight repeal. And I think there's an expectation that we're going to get to conference and be able to go forward with the Senate and the House and do the repeal and replace.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: All right, onto taxes.  The president seemed to indicate that he's still a fan of getting across- the-board tax relief, but maybe not totally across-the-board, that the rich could be left out. They might even pay more.   What did you think of that?

utterances.speaker: ROMNEY MCDANIEL
utterances.sentences: Well, I think the president is looking at, how do we stimulate our economy and how do we help the middle class?  The middle class has been overburdened. Their wages have been stagnant. They have taken the brunt of ObamaCare with premiums doubling and deductibles so high. And that's his first priority. I think it's still in progress. We're going to see a robust discussion on that. But we need to help the middle class of the United States of America, and they need tax relief.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Do you think the rich, Ronna, don't pay enough?

utterances.speaker: ROMNEY MCDANIEL
utterances.sentences: Well, I don't know how you define rich. So let's see what he's putting as rich. If it's somebody who is making $5 million a year, we'll see where that is. I certainly don't think I can say which person is rich or not. We will have to see what the Senate and the House and the...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: The reason why I ask, I know met with Robert Kraft, who owns the New England Patriots, and was talking a little bit with Steve Bannon sometime back, his strategist, who was an advocate, we're told -- I could be very wrong -- for higher taxes on the wealthy. And you're quite right. I don't know where that began. Let's say it was the $500,000-and-over club. But I could be wrong. But the message some fear on the Hill that could be sending is that, is this president dialing back the size of tax cuts at this point, when the focus will be on the middle class, as you argue, as Republicans think it should be, Democrats think it should be, and on corporate taxes, but they as a group will not be included?

utterances.speaker: ROMNEY MCDANIEL
utterances.sentences: Well, and they're going to have to take a look at the numbers and make sure it adds up.  I think the priority, as you said, is the middle class. That makes sense. They're taking the brunt of everything, from health care to stagnant wages.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But it sounds like they're crunching numbers, Ronna. I get the idea that someone is crunching numbers and doing this.

utterances.speaker: ROMNEY MCDANIEL
utterances.sentences: Yes, they are, yes.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: And they're saying, geez, the rich thing, that won't work.

utterances.speaker: ROMNEY MCDANIEL
utterances.sentences: Well, I don't think so. I think they have to look at the numbers and how they add up and we have to help the middle class. We have got get the economy humming and do a corporate tax cut.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ROMNEY MCDANIEL
utterances.sentences: And then you have got to look at what you can do and how we fund the things that we need to fund, like our military and all the other things that we have to take care of.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Gotcha. What do you think of this Jeff Sessions dustup? A lot of Republicans, maybe owing to the uniqueness of the club we call the United States Senate, don't like the way the president has been treating him and dragging him out in the mud here.  Among them -- and these are people that I have talked to, Chuck Grassley, and Richard Shelby, and Thom Tillis, and all of them saying, you know, no, no, no, this guy did the right thing when he recused himself on the Russia thing, and this is no way to treat someone who was a very loyal and early supporter of the president.

utterances.speaker: ROMNEY MCDANIEL
utterances.sentences: Well, I wasn't part of their discussions early on. But I think the president feels like, if Jeff Sessions knew that he was going to recuse himself, that's something he should have let the president know. That should have gone into the president's decision-making.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But that developed later, right, in the process of this. That developed later, that that revelation of a meeting came up, where he almost had to do it.   Every senator I have talked to, Republican and Democrat, every legal scholar I have talked to -- and I'm no lawyer -- said that that was the right thing to do. What do you think?

utterances.speaker: ROMNEY MCDANIEL
utterances.sentences: But you don't know if they had discussions early on saying, if this happens, would you recuse yourself? We don't know what their personal discussions were for Jeff Sessions to get that job of attorney general. This is what I know. The president is a fighter. He wants people who are going to fight back on his behalf.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: I know, but he's fighting with his attorney general in a very ugly, public way. Why doesn't he just fire the guy?

utterances.speaker: ROMNEY MCDANIEL
utterances.sentences: He is saying, I want people in my administration to fight against this false narrative that the Democrats keep putting forward that there was collusion between Trump campaign and Russia.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: But, you know, Ronna, he's just humiliating the guy.

utterances.speaker: ROMNEY MCDANIEL
utterances.sentences: Well, he's letting him know that he's not happy. And then there's things I'm sure he's happy with, too. And we saw Jeff Sessions today is going to look into the leaks. And I think that is something he should be doing.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Are you surprised, Ronna, that Sessions hasn't quit?

utterances.speaker: ROMNEY MCDANIEL
utterances.sentences: No, I'm not.  I don't know the back and forth between the White House. Frankly, this isn't surprising with the president. I like -- if he says, hey, I don't like what you're doing. He's straightforward.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: Yes, but tell me to my face. Don't tell the nation or tweet it the world. Tell me to my face.

utterances.speaker: ROMNEY MCDANIEL
utterances.sentences: Well, he may be. We don't know.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: All right, we will see. Ronna McDaniel, thank you very much. Good seeing you.

utterances.speaker: ROMNEY MCDANIEL
utterances.sentences: Thanks for having me, Neil.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.sentences: All right. END Content and Programming Copyright 2017 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. Copyright 2017 CQ-Roll Call, Inc.
